SVD Computation

Posted on 2018-05-21 Edited on 2021-04-29

Singular vector decomposition is one of the highlights of linear algebra.

Review of Linear Transformation

Before diving into the topic, we have a brief review of linear transformation. Given a matrix A∈Rm×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}A∈Rm×n with rank rrr, we can view it as a linear transformation from f:Rn→Rmf: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^mf:Rn→Rm defined as

f(x)=Ax,∀x∈Rn. f(x) = Ax, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}^n. f(x)=Ax,∀x∈Rn.

It maps a vector in the row space, i.e., the subspace spanned by row vectors of AAA, to a vector in the column space, the subspace spanned by column vectors of AAA.

Define

  1. S(AT)={∑i=1nλiA[i,:]:λi∈R,∀i∈[n]}S(A^T) = \{ \sum_{i = 1}^n \lambda_i A[i,:] : \lambda_i \in \mathbb{R}, \forall i \in [n] \}S(AT)={∑i=1n​λi​A[i,:]:λi​∈R,∀i∈[n]}, which we call the row space of AAA.

  2. N(AT)={x∈Rm,s.t.,Ax=0}N(A^T) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^m, s.t., Ax = 0\}N(AT)={x∈Rm,s.t.,Ax=0}, the subspace perpendicular to S(AT)S(A^T)S(AT).

  3. S(A)={∑i=1mλiA[:,i]:λi∈R,∀i∈[m]}S(A) = \{ \sum_{i = 1}^m \lambda_i A[:,i] : \lambda_i \in \mathbb{R}, \forall i \in [m] \}S(A)={∑i=1m​λi​A[:,i]:λi​∈R,∀i∈[m]}, the columns space of AAA.

  4. N(A)N(A)N(A) the space perpendicular to S(A)S(A)S(A).

Note that S(AT)S(A^T)S(AT) and S(A)S(A)S(A) has the same dimension rrr. For any x∈Rnx \in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn, we can write x=y+zx = y + zx=y+z, such that y∈S(AT)y \in S(A^T)y∈S(AT) and z∈N(AT)z \in N(A^T)z∈N(AT). The operation Ax=Ay+AzAx = Ay + AzAx=Ay+Az, takes the yyy component to a vector in S(A)S(A)S(A) and the zzz component to point 000, as illustrated by the figure.

Singular Vector Decomposition

Singular vector decomposition aims to find

  1. an orthonormal basis {v1,v2,...,vr}\{ v_1, v_2, ..., v_r \}{v1​,v2​,...,vr​} for S(AT)S(A^T)S(AT),
  2. and an orthogonal base {u1,u2,...,ur}\{ u_1, u_2, ..., u_r \}{u1​,u2​,...,ur​} for S(A)S(A)S(A),
  3. such that f(vi)=Avi=σiuif(v_i) = A v_i = \sigma_i u_if(vi​)=Avi​=σi​ui​ for all i∈[r]i \in [r]i∈[r] and σ1≥σ2≥...≥σr>0\sigma_1 \ge \sigma_2 \ge ... \ge \sigma_r > 0σ1​≥σ2​≥...≥σr​>0.

When restricted to the sets {v1,v2,...,vr}\{ v_1, v_2, ..., v_r \}{v1​,v2​,...,vr​} and {u1,u2,...,ur}\{ u_1, u_2, ..., u_r \}{u1​,u2​,...,ur​}, fff is a bijection.

If we write V=[v1,v2,...,vr]V = [v_1, v_2, ..., v_r]V=[v1​,v2​,...,vr​],

Σ=[σ1σ2...σr] \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} &\sigma_1 \\ &&\sigma_2 \\ &&& ... \\ &&&&\sigma_r \end{bmatrix} Σ=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​​σ1​​σ2​​...​σr​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​

and U=[u1,u2,...,ur]U = [u_1, u_2, ..., u_r]U=[u1​,u2​,...,ur​], then

AV=UΣ. A V = U \Sigma. AV=UΣ.

As the columns of VVV are orthonormal vectors, it is invertible and V−1=VTV^{-1} = V^TV−1=VT. Hence

A=UΣV−1=UΣVT A = U \Sigma V^{-1} = U \Sigma V^T A=UΣV−1=UΣVT

Equivalently, it holds that

A=σ1u1v1T+σ2u2v2T+...+σrurvrT. A = \sigma_1 u_1 v_1^T + \sigma_2 u_2 v_2^T + ... + \sigma_r u_r v_r^T. A=σ1​u1​v1T​+σ2​u2​v2T​+...+σr​ur​vrT​.

Further,

ATA=VΣ2VT,AAT=UΣ2UT. A^T A = V \Sigma^2 V^T, A A^T = U \Sigma^2 U^T. ATA=VΣ2VT,AAT=UΣ2UT.

which implies that

ATAV=VΣ2,AATU=UΣ2. A^T A V = V \Sigma^2, A A^T U = U \Sigma^2. ATAV=VΣ2,AATU=UΣ2.

The viv_ivi​’s and uiu_iui​’s are eigenvectors of ATAA^T AATA and AATA A^TAAT respectively.

EXISTENCE

The key is ATAA^T AATA, which is semi-positive. Since

ATAx=0⇔xATAx=0⇔Ax=0, A^T A x = 0 \Leftrightarrow x A^T A x = 0 \Leftrightarrow Ax = 0, ATAx=0⇔xATAx=0⇔Ax=0,

ATAA^T AATA and AAA has the rank rrr, the same null space and hence the same row space. Further, as ATAA^T AATA is semi-positive, it has rrr positive eigenvalue. Denote the eigenvalues of ATAA^TAATA in decreasing order as λ1≥λ2≥...≥λr>0\lambda_1 \ge \lambda_2 \ge ... \ge \lambda_r > 0λ1​≥λ2​≥...≥λr​>0 and the corresponding (unit length) eigenvectors as v1,v2,...,vrv_1, v_2, ..., v_rv1​,v2​,...,vr​. The viv_ivi​’s are orthogonal, as

  • For i≠ji \neq ji=j, viTATAvj=λiviTvj=λjviTvjv_i^T A^T A v_j = \lambda_i v_i^T v_j = \lambda_j v_i^T v_jviT​ATAvj​=λi​viT​vj​=λj​viT​vj​. As λi≠λj\lambda_i \neq \lambda_jλi​=λj​, viTvj=0v_i^T v_j = 0viT​vj​=0.

They constitute an orthogonal base of the row space of ATAA^T AATA and the row space AAA.

Now we use the viv_ivi​’s to search for uiu_iui​’s as follows: let σ=λi\sigma = \sqrt{\lambda_i}σ=λi​​, we claim that

ui≐1σiAvi,∀i∈[r] u_i \doteq \frac{1}{\sigma_i} A v_i, \forall i \in [r] ui​≐σi​1​Avi​,∀i∈[r]

are orthonormal.

  1. The uiu_iui​’s are orthogonal: uiTuj=1σiσjviTATAvj=σj2σiσjviTvj=0u_i^T u_j = \frac{1}{\sigma_i \sigma_j} v_i^T A^T A v_j = \frac{\sigma_j^2 }{\sigma_i \sigma_j} v_i^T v_j = 0uiT​uj​=σi​σj​1​viT​ATAvj​=σi​σj​σj2​​viT​vj​=0
  2. The uiu_iui​’s are unite vectors: uiTui=1σi2viTATAvi=1u_i^T u_i = \frac{1}{\sigma_i^2} v_i^T A^T A v_i = 1uiT​ui​=σi2​1​viT​ATAvi​=1

Hence uiu_iui​’s constitutes an orthonormal basis. As the columns of AAA has dimension rrr, the uiu_iui​’s covers the entire columns space. This completes the proof.
■\blacksquare■

GEOMETRIC INTERPRETATION

To understand the geometry of SVD, we first extend the matrix VVV to an orthogonal base in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn and UUU to an orthogonal base in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm. By adding proper zero rows and columns to Σ\SigmaΣ, we still have A=UΣVTA = U \Sigma V^TA=UΣVT.

Now, the transformation f(x)f(x)f(x) is decomposed into three steps:

x→VTx→Σ(VTx)→U(ΣVTx)x \rightarrow V^Tx \rightarrow \Sigma (V^T x) \rightarrow U(\Sigma V^T x) x→VTx→Σ(VTx)→U(ΣVTx)

It suffices to under the effect of multiplying an orthogonal matrix VVV. It is indeed a rotation. To see this, multiply VVV by eie_iei​ gives viv_ivi​, i.e., Vei=viV e_i = v_iVei​=vi​, for all for i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n]. Therefore, VVV takes the orthogonal base I=[e1,e2,...,en]I = [e_1, e_2, ..., e_n]I=[e1​,e2​,...,en​] to the orthogonal base V=[v1,v2,...,vn]V = [v_1, v_2, ..., v_n]V=[v1​,v2​,...,vn​].

Note that the inverse V−1V^{-1}V−1 of VVV is also an orthogonal matrix and hence a rotation. Indeed it rotates the orthogonal base V=[v1,v2,...,vn]V = [v_1, v_2, ..., v_n]V=[v1​,v2​,...,vn​] back to I=[e1,e2,...,en]I = [e_1, e_2, ..., e_n]I=[e1​,e2​,...,en​]. To understand this, observe that V−1=VTV^{-1} = V^TV−1=VT. For arbitrary viv_ivi​, we have VTvi=eiV^T v_i = e_iVTvi​=ei​.

Therefore, VTxV^T xVTx corresponds to a rotation, in the reverse direction to the one defined by VVV.

Next, the matrix Σ\SigmaΣ scales the iii-th dimension of VTxV^T xVTx by σi\sigma_iσi​, for all i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n]. Combined with the first step, if x=vix = v_ix=vi​, then it is first rotation to the direction eie_iei​, then scaled by a factor σi\sigma_iσi​.

Finally, UUU is an orthogonal matrix and corresponds to another rotation, which take ei∈Rme_i \in \mathbb{R}^mei​∈Rm to a vector uiu_iui​.

Corollary: Define the Frobenius norm of a matrix AAA as

∥A∣F=∑i,jai,j2\Vert A|_F = \sqrt{\sum_{i, j} a_{i, j}^2 } ∥A∣F​=i,j∑​ai,j2​​

Then ∥A∥F2=∥Σ∥2=∑i=1rσi2\Vert A\Vert _F^2 = \Vert \Sigma\Vert ^2 = \sum_{i = 1}^r \sigma_i^2∥A∥F2​=∥Σ∥2=∑i=1r​σi2​.

Proof: Note that rotating the vectors do not change their distance from the origin. Recall that UTU^TUT and VVV are both rotations. Hence ∥A∥F2=∥AV∥F2=∥UTAV∥F2=∥UTUΣVTV∥F2=∥Σ∥F2\Vert A\Vert _F^2 = \Vert AV\Vert _F^2 = \Vert U^T A V\Vert _F^2 = \Vert U^T U \Sigma V^T V\Vert _F^2= \Vert \Sigma\Vert _F^2∥A∥F2​=∥AV∥F2​=∥UTAV∥F2​=∥UTUΣVTV∥F2​=∥Σ∥F2​.

□\square□.

APPLICATIONS

An important property of the viv_ivi​ is that

  1. v1=arg⁡max⁡v∈Rn,∥v∥=1∥Av∥v_1 = \arg\max_{v \in \mathbb{R}^n, \Vert v\Vert = 1} \Vert Av\Vertv1​=argmaxv∈Rn,∥v∥=1​∥Av∥.
  2. v2=arg⁡max⁡v∈Rn,∥v∥=1,v⊥v1∥Av∥v_2 = \arg\max_{v \in \mathbb{R}^n, \Vert v\Vert = 1, v \perp v_1} \Vert Av \Vertv2​=argmaxv∈Rn,∥v∥=1,v⊥v1​​∥Av∥.
  3. …
  4. vr=arg⁡max⁡v∈Rn,∥v∥=1,v⊥v1,v⊥v2,...,v⊥vr−1∥Av∥v_r = \arg\max_{v \in \mathbb{R}^n, \Vert v\Vert = 1, v \perp v_1, v \perp v_2, ..., v \perp v_{r - 1}} \Vert Av \Vertvr​=argmaxv∈Rn,∥v∥=1,v⊥v1​,v⊥v2​,...,v⊥vr−1​​∥Av∥

Proof: For any v∈Rn,∥v∥=1v \in \mathbb{R}^n, \Vert v\Vert = 1v∈Rn,∥v∥=1, we can write v=∑i=1naiviv = \sum_{i = 1}^n a_i v_iv=∑i=1n​ai​vi​, where ∑i=1nai2=1\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 1∑i=1n​ai2​=1, since viv_ivi​’s are an orthogonal base. Then

∥Av∥2=xTATAx=xTVΣUTUΣVTx=∥ΣVTx∥2=∑i=1rai2σi2\begin{aligned} \Vert Av\Vert ^2 &= x^T A^T A x \\ &= x^T V \Sigma U^T U \Sigma V^T x \\ &= \Vert \Sigma V^T x\Vert ^2 \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^r a_i^2 \sigma_i^2 \end{aligned} ∥Av∥2​=xTATAx=xTVΣUTUΣVTx=∥ΣVTx∥2=i=1∑r​ai2​σi2​​

which is maximized to σ12\sigma_1^2σ12​ when a1=1a_1 = 1a1​=1 and ai=0,i≥2a_i = 0, i \ge 2ai​=0,i≥2. Hence (1) is proved.

Similarly, when ∥v∥=1,v⊥v1,v2,...,vk\Vert v\Vert = 1, v \perp v_1, v_2, ..., v_k∥v∥=1,v⊥v1​,v2​,...,vk​ for some k<rk < rk<r, then a1=a2=...ak=0a_1 = a_2 = ... a_k = 0a1​=a2​=...ak​=0, and v=∑i=k+1raiviv = \sum_{i = k + 1}^r a_i v_iv=∑i=k+1r​ai​vi​.

∥Av∥2=∑i=k+1rai2σi2\begin{aligned} \Vert Av\Vert ^2 &= \sum_{i = k + 1}^r a_i^2 \sigma_i^2 \end{aligned} ∥Av∥2​=i=k+1∑r​ai2​σi2​​

which achieves maximum when ak+1=1a_{k + 1} = 1ak+1​=1 and ai=0,i>k+1a_i = 0, i > k + 1ai​=0,i>k+1. In this case v=vk+1v = v_{k + 1}v=vk+1​.

Best Fit kkk subspace

An implication is that, the subspace space VkV_kVk​ spanned by (v1,v2,...,vk)(v_1, v_2, ..., v_k)(v1​,v2​,...,vk​), is the best kkk-dimension subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn that fits the row vectors of AAA, namely, A[1,:],A[2,:],...,A[m,:]A[1, :], A[2, :], ..., A[m, :]A[1,:],A[2,:],...,A[m,:]. Here fits mean the sum of the square of the perpendicular distance from the row vector to their projections on the subspace is minimized. Denote SSS any subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, then for v∈Rnv \in \mathbb{R}^nv∈Rn, we can decompose vvv into two part: the part vSv_SvS​ that is within SSS and the part vS⊥v_{S_\perp}vS⊥​​ perpendicular to SSS. Then

∥v∥2=∥vS∥2+∥vS⊥∥2\Vert v\Vert ^2 = \Vert v_{S}\Vert ^2 + \Vert v_{S_\perp}\Vert ^2 ∥v∥2=∥vS​∥2+∥vS⊥​​∥2

Minimizing ∥vS⊥∥2\Vert v_{S_\perp}\Vert ^2∥vS⊥​​∥2 is equivalent to maximizing ∥vS∥2\Vert v_{S}\Vert ^2∥vS​∥2. The subspace space by (v1,v2,...,vk)(v_1, v_2, ..., v_k)(v1​,v2​,...,vk​) is the subspace that maximize the sum of the squares of the projections of row vectors to the subspace.

We prove this by induction. When k=1k = 1k=1, the proof holds trivially by the definition of v1v_1v1​. In particular, Av1A v_1Av1​ is the lengths of the projections of the row to the line that go through v1v_1v1​, since v1v_1v1​ is a unit vector. Further, the corresponding projected vectors in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn are

Av1v1T=σ1u1v1TAv_1 v_1^T = \sigma_1 u_1 v_1^T Av1​v1T​=σ1​u1​v1T​

For general kkk, by induction hypothesis Vk−1V_{k - 1}Vk−1​ is the best k−1k-1k−1 dimension space that fit rows of AAA. Denote N(Vk−1)N(V_{k -1})N(Vk−1​) the subspace that is perpendicular to Vk−1V_{k - 1}Vk−1​, which has dimension n−k+1n - k + 1n−k+1. For any kkk dimensional subspace S∩N(Vk−1)≠∅S \cap N(V_{k - 1}) \neq \emptysetS∩N(Vk−1​)=∅, since dim(S)+dim(N(Vk−1))=k+n−k+1≥ndim(S) + dim(N(V_{k - 1})) = k + n - k + 1 \ge ndim(S)+dim(N(Vk−1​))=k+n−k+1≥n. Let sk∈S∩N(Vk−1)s_k \in S \cap N(V_{k - 1})sk​∈S∩N(Vk−1​) be a unit vector. By the definition of vkv_kvk​, we have

∥Avk∥2≥∥Ask∥2\Vert Av_k\Vert ^2 \ge \Vert As_k\Vert ^2 ∥Avk​∥2≥∥Ask​∥2

Now we can extend sks_ksk​ to a base of SSS, denoted as s1,s2,...,sks_1, s_2, ..., s_ks1​,s2​,...,sk​. By induction hypothesis, it holds

∑i=1k−1∥Avi∥2≥∑i=1k−1∥Asi∥2\sum_{i = 1}^{k - 1} \Vert A v_i\Vert ^2 \ge \sum_{i = 1}^{k - 1} \Vert A s_i\Vert ^2 i=1∑k−1​∥Avi​∥2≥i=1∑k−1​∥Asi​∥2

Hence

∑i=1k∥Avi∥2≥∑i=1k∥Asi∥2\sum_{i = 1}^{k} \Vert A v_i\Vert ^2 \ge \sum_{i = 1}^{k} \Vert A s_i\Vert ^2 i=1∑k​∥Avi​∥2≥i=1∑k​∥Asi​∥2

But the former is exactly sum of the squares of the lengths of the projections to VkV_kVk​ and the later is the one to SSS. Finally, we mention that the projection of AAA to VkV_kVk​ is given by

Ak=∑i=1kσiuiviTA_k = \sum_{i = 1}^k \sigma_i u_i v_i ^T Ak​=i=1∑k​σi​ui​viT​

Corollary 1.
For any rank kkk matrix BBB, we have

∥A−Ak∥F≤∥A−B∥F\Vert A - A_k\Vert _F \le \Vert A - B\Vert _F ∥A−Ak​∥F​≤∥A−B∥F​

Intuitively, if we view square root of the sum of square distance of row vectors to the origin (note that the origin can be viewed as a zero dimension subspace.)

Corollary 2. Define the 2-norm of a matrix AAA as

∥A∥2=σ1=max⁡v∈Rn,∥v∥=1∥Av∥ \Vert A \Vert _2 = \sigma_1 = \max_{v \in \mathbb{R}^n, \Vert v\Vert = 1} \Vert Av \Vert ∥A∥2​=σ1​=v∈Rn,∥v∥=1max​∥Av∥

The 222-norm is the square root of the maximum sum of squares of the projections of the row vectors to a one dimension subspace. Then an implication of the SVD is that, for any rank kkk matrix BBB, we have

∥A−Ak∥2≤∥A−B∥2\Vert A - A_k\Vert _2 \le \Vert A - B\Vert _2 ∥A−Ak​∥2​≤∥A−B∥2​

Proof: First note that for v=∑i=1raiviv = \sum_{i = 1}^r a_i v_iv=∑i=1r​ai​vi​, such that ∑i=1kai2=1\sum_{i = 1}^k a_i^2 = 1∑i=1k​ai2​=1,

∥(A−Ak)v∥=∑i=k+1raiσi \Vert (A - A_k) v\Vert = \sum_{i = k + 1}^r a_i \sigma_i ∥(A−Ak​)v∥=i=k+1∑r​ai​σi​

it is maximized when ak+1=1a_{k + 1} = 1ak+1​=1 and ∥A−Ak∥2=σk+1\Vert A - A_k\Vert _2 = \sigma_{k + 1}∥A−Ak​∥2​=σk+1​. Now, as dim(Ak+1)+dim(N(BT))=k+1+n−k≥ndim(A_{k + 1}) + dim(N(B^T)) = k + 1 + n - k \ge ndim(Ak+1​)+dim(N(BT))=k+1+n−k≥n, ∃v∈Rn\exists v \in \mathbb{R}^n∃v∈Rn, such that Bv=0Bv = 0Bv=0 and v=∑i=1k+1aiviv = \sum_{i = 1}^{k + 1} a_i v_iv=∑i=1k+1​ai​vi​ and ∥v∥=1\Vert v\Vert = 1∥v∥=1. Now

∥A−B∥2≥∥(A−B)v∥=∥Av∥=∑i=1k+1ai2σi2≥σk+1 \Vert A - B\Vert _2 \ge \Vert (A - B)v\Vert = \Vert Av\Vert = \sqrt{\sum_{i = 1}^{k + 1} a_i^2 \sigma_i^2 } \ge \sigma_{k + 1} ∥A−B∥2​≥∥(A−B)v∥=∥Av∥=i=1∑k+1​ai2​σi2​​≥σk+1​

which finishes our proof.

Computing SVD

If suffices to compute the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of ATAA^T AATA, i.e., σi2\sigma_i^2σi2​’s and viv_ivi​’s. In the simplest case, σ1>σ2≥σ3≥...≥σr\sigma_1 > \sigma_2 \ge \sigma_3 \ge ... \ge \sigma_rσ1​>σ2​≥σ3​≥...≥σr​, then we can take powers of ATAA^T AATA,

(ATA)k=VΣ2kVT=∑i=1rσi2kviviT (A^T A)^k = V \Sigma^{2k} V^T = \sum_{i = 1}^r \sigma_i^{2k} v_i v_i^T (ATA)k=VΣ2kVT=i=1∑r​σi2k​vi​viT​

Dividing the matrix by σ12k\sigma_1^{2k}σ12k​,

1σ12k(ATA)k=VΣ2kVT=v1v1T+∑i=2rσi2kσ12kviviT \frac{1}{\sigma_1^{2k} } (A^T A)^k = V \Sigma^{2k} V^T = v_1 v_1^T + \sum_{i = 2}^r \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{\sigma_1^{2k} } v_i v_i^T σ12k​1​(ATA)k=VΣ2kVT=v1​v1T​+i=2∑r​σ12k​σi2k​​vi​viT​

The second part converges to 0 as k→∞k \rightarrow \inftyk→∞. Then for any vector vvv that is not perpendicular to v1v_1v1​, we have

lim⁡k1σ12k(ATA)kv=v1(v1Tv)=(v1Tv)v1 \lim_k \frac{1}{\sigma_1^{2k} } (A^T A)^k v = v_1 (v_1^T v) = (v_1^T v) v_1 klim​σ12k​1​(ATA)kv=v1​(v1T​v)=(v1T​v)v1​

which is a multiple of v1v_1v1​. Normalizing the vector recovers v1v_1v1​.

When there is a tie of the largest eigenvalues, that is σ1=σ2=...=σt\sigma_1 = \sigma_2 = ... = \sigma_tσ1​=σ2​=...=σt​ for some t<rt < rt<r, and suppose that vvv is not perpendicular to v1,v2,...,vtv_1, v_2, ..., v_tv1​,v2​,...,vt​ simultaneously, then

lim⁡k1σ12k(ATA)kv=the projection of v to Vt \lim_k \frac{1}{\sigma_1^{2k} } (A^T A)^k v = \text{the projection of } v \text { to } V_t klim​σ12k​1​(ATA)kv=the projection of v to Vt​

Suppose we are satisfied with this result, we still need to address two problems.

  1. We use σ12k\sigma_1^{2k}σ12k​ to normalize the resulting vector, which is unknown.
  2. How can we find a vector vvv that is not perpendicular to all v1,..,vtv_1, .., v_tv1​,..,vt​ simultaneously, i.e., its projection to VtV_tVt​ is not zero.

We defer the discussion of the first issue. As for the second issue, we tackle the problem for picking a vector vvv uniformly at random from the nnn-dimension unit ball, and then normalize it by $v / \Vert v\Vert $, in the hope that it is a “good” vector.

Lemma: With probability at least 1/21 / 21/2, that vTv1≥1/nv^T v_1 \ge 1 /\sqrt{n}vTv1​≥1/n​.

Proof: By symmetry of the nnn-dimension unit ball, it suffices to show that for an arbitrary given fixed direction, the projection of vvv to that direction is at least 1/4n1 / 4 \sqrt n1/4n​ with probability 1/21 / 21/2. For convenience, we choose this direction to be e1e_1e1​.

Denote the volume of an nnn-dimensional unit ball as V(n)V(n)V(n).

Now, we would like to use two cylinders to estimate the probability of ∣e1Tv∣/∥v∥≤14n|e_1 ^T v| / \Vert v\Vert \le \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n}∣e1T​v∣/∥v∥≤4n​1​.

Note that the points {v}\{v \}{v} inside the ball with e1Tv/∥v∥≤14ne_1^T v / \Vert v\Vert \le \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n}e1T​v/∥v∥≤4n​1​ is completely contained in a cylinder centered in the equator, with radius one and height 14n\frac{1}{4 \sqrt n}4n​1​ that is parallel to e1e_1e1​. Its volume is given by 14nV(n−1)\frac{1}{4 \sqrt n} V(n - 1)4n​1​V(n−1). Hence:

Pr⁡[∣vTe1∣≤14n]≤214nV(n−1)V(n) \Pr \left[ |v^T e_1| \le \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n} \right] \le \frac{2 \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n} V(n - 1)}{V(n)} Pr[∣vTe1​∣≤4n​1​]≤V(n)24n​1​V(n−1)​

On the other hand, we can use a cylinder centered at the equator to lower bound the volume of nnn-dimension unit ball. The cylinder is inside the ball, with height 21n2\frac{1}{\sqrt n}2n​1​ and radius (1−(1n)2)1/2(1 - (\frac{1}{ \sqrt n})^2)^{1/ 2}(1−(n​1​)2)1/2 . Therefore,

V(n)≥21n(1−(1n)2)(n−1)/2V(n−1)≥21n(1−1n)n/2V(n−1)\begin{aligned} V(n) & \ge 2 \frac{1}{\sqrt n} \left(1 - (\frac{1}{\sqrt n})^2 \right)^{(n - 1) / 2} V(n - 1) \\ &\ge 2 \frac{1}{\sqrt n} \left( 1 - \frac{1}{n} \right)^{n / 2} V(n - 1) \end{aligned} V(n)​≥2n​1​(1−(n​1​)2)(n−1)/2V(n−1)≥2n​1​(1−n1​)n/2V(n−1)​

Note that (1−1n)n(1 - \frac{1}{n})^n(1−n1​)n increases with nnn, and for n≥2n \ge 2n≥2, (1−1n)n≥14(1 - \frac{1}{n})^n \ge \frac{1}{4}(1−n1​)n≥41​ and (1−1n)n/2≥12\left( 1 - \frac{1}{n} \right)^{n / 2} \ge \frac{1}{2}(1−n1​)n/2≥21​

Pr⁡[vTe1≤14n]≤14nV(n−1)V(n)≤12 \Pr \left[ v^T e_1 \le \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n} \right] \le \frac{\frac{1}{4 \sqrt n} V(n - 1)}{V(n)} \le \frac{1}{2} Pr[vTe1​≤4n​1​]≤V(n)4n​1​V(n−1)​≤21​

□\square□

Theorem After 1ϵln⁡nϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{n}{\epsilon}ϵ1​lnϵn​ iterations, we can obtain a vector whose component that is perpendicular to VtV_tVt​ is at most ϵ\epsilonϵ fraction of its square length, with probability at least 12\frac{1}{2}21​.

Proof: If σi<(1−ϵ)σ1\sigma_i < (1 - \epsilon) \sigma_1σi​<(1−ϵ)σ1​, then

σi2k∑j=1kσ12k≤σiσ12k≤(1−ϵ)2k \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } \le \frac{\sigma_i}{\sigma_1}^{2k} \le (1-\epsilon)^{2k} ∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​≤σ1​σi​​2k≤(1−ϵ)2k

Denote σ1=σ2=...=σt\sigma_1 = \sigma_2 = ... = \sigma_tσ1​=σ2​=...=σt​ for some t<rt < rt<r the largest singular values. By the previous lemma, we pick a vvv from the unit ball at random, and take $v \leftarrow v / \Vert v\Vert $. Denote v=∑i=1naiviv = \sum_{i = 1}^n {a_i} v_iv=∑i=1n​ai​vi​, then with probability at least 1/21/ 21/2 we have ∑i=1tai2≥14n\sqrt{ \sum_{i = 1}^t a_i^2} \ge \frac{1}{4 \sqrt n}∑i=1t​ai2​​≥4n​1​. On the other hand, vvv is a unit vector, hence ∑i=1nai2=1\sum_{i = 1}^n a_i^2 = 1∑i=1n​ai2​=1. Therefore, ∑i=t+1nai2≤1−116n\sum_{i = t + 1}^n a_i^2 \le 1 - \frac{1}{16 n}∑i=t+1n​ai2​≤1−16n1​

Now

1∥(ATA)k∥F(ATA)kv=∑i=1rσi2k∑j=1kσ12kviviTv=∑i=1raiσi2k∑j=1kσ12kvi=∑i=1tσi2k∑j=1kσ12kaivi+∑i=t+1rσi2k∑j=1kσ12kaivi\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{\Vert (A^T A)^{k} \Vert _F } (A^T A)^k v &= \sum_{i = 1}^r \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } v_i v_i^T v \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^r \frac{a_i \sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } v_i \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^t \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i v_i + \sum_{i = t + 1}^r \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i v_i \end{aligned} ∥(ATA)k∥F​1​(ATA)kv​=i=1∑r​∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​vi​viT​v=i=1∑r​∑j=1k​σ12k​ai​σi2k​​vi​=i=1∑t​∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​vi​+i=t+1∑r​∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​vi​​

For the second term

∥∑i=t+1rσi2k∑j=1kσ12kaivi∥2=∑i=t+1r(σi2k∑j=1kσ12kai)2≤∑i=t+1r(σi2k∑j=1tσ12kai)2≤(1−ϵ)4kt2∑i=t+1rai2≤(1−ϵ)4kt2\begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i = t + 1}^r \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i v_i \right\Vert ^2 &= \sum_{i = t + 1}^r (\frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i)^2 \\ &\le \sum_{i = t + 1}^r (\frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^t \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i)^2 \\ &\le \frac{ (1 - \epsilon)^{4k} }{t^2} \sum_{i = t + 1}^r a_i^2 \\ &\le \frac{ (1 - \epsilon)^{4k} }{t^2} \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=t+1∑r​∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​vi​∥∥∥∥∥∥​2​=i=t+1∑r​(∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​)2≤i=t+1∑r​(∑j=1t​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​)2≤t2(1−ϵ)4k​i=t+1∑r​ai2​≤t2(1−ϵ)4k​​

For the first term

∥∑i=1tσi2k∑j=1kσ12kaivi∥2=∑i=1t(σi2k∑j=1kσ12k)2ai2≥∑i=1t(1t+(n−t)(1−ϵ)2k)2ai2≥(1t+n(1−ϵ)2k)2∑i=1tai2≥(1t+n(1−ϵ)2k)2116n\begin{aligned} \left\Vert \sum_{i = 1}^t \frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} } a_i v_i \right\Vert^2 &= \sum_{i = 1}^t (\frac{\sigma_i^{2k}}{ \sum_{j = 1}^k \sigma_1^{2k} })^2 a_i^2 \\ &\ge \sum_{i = 1}^t (\frac{ 1 }{ t + (n - t)(1 - \epsilon)^{2k} })^2 a_i^2 \\ &\ge (\frac{ 1 }{ t + n (1 - \epsilon)^{2k} } )^2 \sum_{i = 1}^t a_i^2 \\ &\ge (\frac{ 1 }{ t + n (1 - \epsilon)^{2k} } )^2 \frac{1}{16n} \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥∥​i=1∑t​∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​ai​vi​∥∥∥∥∥∥​2​=i=1∑t​(∑j=1k​σ12k​σi2k​​)2ai2​≥i=1∑t​(t+(n−t)(1−ϵ)2k1​)2ai2​≥(t+n(1−ϵ)2k1​)2i=1∑t​ai2​≥(t+n(1−ϵ)2k1​)216n1​​

If we take k=O(1ϵln⁡nϵ)k = O( \frac{1}{\epsilon} \ln \frac{n}{\epsilon})k=O(ϵ1​lnϵn​), then the second term is at most ϵ\epsilonϵ fraction of the first term.

Remark: picking a point uniformly at random can be done as follows: first pick a point vvv uniformly at random from the high dimension cube: [−1,1]n[-1, 1]^n[−1,1]n, then checks whether the point is inside the ball (∥v∥<1\Vert v\Vert < 1∥v∥<1). This however, could suffers from efficiency problem as the volume of the ball approaches to 000 as the number of dimension increases. More efficient sampling method is needed. But it is not the current focus of this article.

FORA [1]

Posted on 2018-04-18 Edited on 2018-07-02

Suppose that we know the values of πo(s,t)\pi^o(s, t)πo(s,t) for all t∈Vt \in Vt∈V and r(s,vi)r(s, v_i)r(s,vi​) for all vi∈Vv_i \in Vvi​∈V. We would like to evaluate the value of

π(s,t)=πo(s,t)+∑i=1nr(s,vi)π(vi,t)\pi(s, t) = \pi^o(s, t) + \sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t) π(s,t)=πo(s,t)+i=1∑n​r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)

where π(vi,t)\pi(v_i, t)π(vi​,t) denotes the probability of a random starts from viv_ivi​ and terminate at ttt. Let π~(vi,t)\tilde \pi(v_i, t)π~(vi​,t) be our estimation of π(vi,t)\pi(v_i,t)π(vi​,t), then we have an estimation of π(s,t)\pi(s, t)π(s,t):

π~(s,t)=πo(s,t)+∑i=1nr(s,vi)π~(vi,t)\tilde\pi(s, t) = \pi^o(s, t) + \sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \tilde\pi(v_i, t) π~(s,t)=πo(s,t)+i=1∑n​r(s,vi​)π~(vi​,t)

To get π~(vi,t)\tilde\pi(v_i, t)π~(vi​,t), we perform wiw_iwi​ (a value to be determined latter) random walks that start from viv_ivi​ and count the fraction of walks that terminate at ttt. Formally, let Xi,jX_{i, j}Xi,j​ be a Bernoulli random variable that takes value 1 if the jjj-th walk from viv_ivi​ terminates at ttt. Then

E[Xi,j]=π(vi,t)E[X_{i,j}] = \pi(v_i, t) E[Xi,j​]=π(vi​,t)

Let π~(vi,t)=1wi∑j=1wiXi,j\tilde \pi(v_i, t) = \frac{1}{w_i} \sum_{j = 1}^{w_i} X_{i,j}π~(vi​,t)=wi​1​∑j=1wi​​Xi,j​ , so

E[r(s,vi)π~(vi,t)]=r(s,vi)wi∑j=1wiE[Xi,j]=r(s,vi)π(vi,t)E[r(s, v_i) \tilde \pi(v_i, t)] = \frac{r(s, v_i)}{w_i} \sum_{j = 1}^{w_i} E[X_{i,j}] = r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t) E[r(s,vi​)π~(vi​,t)]=wi​r(s,vi​)​j=1∑wi​​E[Xi,j​]=r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)

A naïve use of Chenoff bound to us wi=Ω(log⁡(1/pfail)ϵ2π(vi,t))w_i = \Omega(\frac{\log (1 / p_{fail} ) }{\epsilon^2 \pi(v_i, t)} )wi​=Ω(ϵ2π(vi​,t)log(1/pfail​)​) (which is even worse than evaluating π(s,t)\pi(s, t)π(s,t) by Monte Carlo directly), such that r(s,vi)π~(vi,t)r(s, v_i) \tilde \pi(v_i, t)r(s,vi​)π~(vi​,t) takes value within [(1−ϵ)r(s,vi)π(vi,t),(1+ϵ)r(s,vi)π(vi,t)]\big[(1 - \epsilon) r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t), (1 + \epsilon) r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t)\big][(1−ϵ)r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t),(1+ϵ)r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)]with probability 1−pfail1 - p_{fail}1−pfail​. The problem here is that when π(vi,t)\pi(v_i, t)π(vi​,t) is small, we need large number of random walks to get a good approximation of it. On the other hand, when π(vi,t)\pi(v_i, t)π(vi​,t) is small, the contribution of r(s,vi)π(vi,t)r(s, v_i)\pi(v_i, t)r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t) to ∑i=1nr(s,vi)π(vi,t)\sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t)∑i=1n​r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t) is small, which means that more deviation is allowed on the estimation of π(vi,t)\pi(v_i, t)π(vi​,t).

What if the amount of deviation on the estimation of r(s,vi)π(vi,t)r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t)r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t) we allow is π(s,t)\pi(s, t)π(s,t)? How about π(s,t)/n\pi(s, t) / nπ(s,t)/n? More clever way of allocating deviation? Better Chernoff bound?

[1] solves this by bounding the cumulative deviation of ∑i=1nr(s,vi)π~(vi,t)\sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \tilde \pi(v_i, t)∑i=1n​r(s,vi​)π~(vi​,t) as a whole. The statistical tool it turns to is a special Chernoff bound:

Theorem

Let Y1,Y2,...,YwY_1, Y_2, ..., Y_wY1​,Y2​,...,Yw​ be independent random variables with

Pr[Yi=1]=piPr[Yi=0]=1−pi.Pr[Y_i = 1] = p_i \qquad Pr[Y_i = 0 ] = 1 - p_i. Pr[Yi​=1]=pi​Pr[Yi​=0]=1−pi​.

Let Y=1w∑i=1wbiYiY = \frac{1}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^w b_i Y_iY=w1​∑i=1w​bi​Yi​ with bi>0b_i > 0bi​>0, and v=1w∑i=1wbi2piv = \frac{1}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^w b_i^2 p_iv=w1​∑i=1w​bi2​pi​. Then

Pr[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥λ]≤2exp⁡(−λ2w2v+2bλ/3)Pr[|Y - E[Y]| \ge \lambda ] \le 2 \exp \big(-\frac{\lambda^2 w} {2 v + 2 b \lambda / 3} \big) Pr[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥λ]≤2exp(−2v+2bλ/3λ2w​)

where b=max⁡{b1,b2,...,bw}b = \max\{ b_1, b_2, ..., b_w\}b=max{b1​,b2​,...,bw​}

To apply this bound, we perform in total w=∑i=1nwiw = \sum_{i = 1}^n w_iw=∑i=1n​wi​ random walks. The first w1w_1w1​ walks starts from v1v_1v1​ , the next w2w_2w2​ walks starts from v2v_2v2​, and so on. Let

{Y1,...,Yw1,Yw1+1,...,Yw1+w2,...,Y∑i=1n−1wi+1,...,Yw}\{ Y_{1}, ..., Y_{w_1}, Y_{w_1 + 1}, ..., Y_{w_1 + w_2}, ..., Y_{\sum_{i = 1}^{n -1}w_i + 1}, ..., Y_{w} \} {Y1​,...,Yw1​​,Yw1​+1​,...,Yw1​+w2​​,...,Y∑i=1n−1​wi​+1​,...,Yw​}

be the corresponding independent indicator random variables that take value 1 if the walks terminate at ttt and

bj=wwir(s,vi)b_j = \frac{w}{w_i} r(s, v_i) bj​=wi​w​r(s,vi​)

if the jjj-th walk starts from vertex viv_ivi​. So

b=max⁡{b1,b2,...,bw}=max⁡1≤i≤nwwir(s,vi)b = \max \{b_1, b_2, ..., b_w\} = \max_{1 \le i \le n} \frac{w}{w_i} r(s, v_i) b=max{b1​,b2​,...,bw​}=1≤i≤nmax​wi​w​r(s,vi​)

It can be verified that

E[Y]=1w∑i=1wE[Yi]=1w∑i=1n∑j=1wiwwir(s,vi)π(vi,t)=∑i=1nr(s,vi)π(vi,t)E[Y] = \frac{1}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^w E[Y_i] = \frac{1}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^n \sum_{j = 1}^{w_i} \frac{w}{w_i} r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t) = \sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t) E[Y]=w1​i=1∑w​E[Yi​]=w1​i=1∑n​j=1∑wi​​wi​w​r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)=i=1∑n​r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)

To bound the deviation of π~(s,t)\tilde \pi(s, t)π~(s,t) from π(s,t)\pi(s, t)π(s,t), we notice that

∣π~(s,t)−π(s,t)∣=∣∑i=1nr(s,vi)π~(vi,t)−∑i=1nr(s,vi)π(vi,t)∣=∣Y−E[Y]∣|\tilde \pi(s, t) - \pi(s, t)| = | \sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \tilde \pi(v_i, t) - \sum_{i = 1}^n r(s, v_i) \pi(v_i, t)| = |Y - E[Y]| ∣π~(s,t)−π(s,t)∣=∣i=1∑n​r(s,vi​)π~(vi​,t)−i=1∑n​r(s,vi​)π(vi​,t)∣=∣Y−E[Y]∣

So

Pr[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥ϵπ(s,t)]≤2exp⁡(−ϵ2π2(s,t) w2v+2bϵπ(s,t)/3)Pr[|Y - E[Y]| \ge \epsilon \pi(s, t)] \le 2 \exp ( - \frac{ \epsilon^2 \pi^2(s, t) \ w}{2 v + 2 b \epsilon \pi(s, t) / 3}) Pr[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥ϵπ(s,t)]≤2exp(−2v+2bϵπ(s,t)/3ϵ2π2(s,t) w​)

But notice that

v=1w∑i=1wbi2pi≤(bw∑i=1wbipi)=b E[Y]≤b π(s,t)v = \frac{1}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^w b_i^2 p_i \le \big( \frac{b}{w} \sum_{i = 1}^w b_i p_i \big) = b \ E[Y] \le b \ \pi(s, t) v=w1​i=1∑w​bi2​pi​≤(wb​i=1∑w​bi​pi​)=b E[Y]≤b π(s,t)

Thus

\begin{align} Pr[|Y - E[Y]| \ge \epsilon \pi(s, t)] &\le 2 \exp ( - \frac{ \epsilon^2 \pi^2(s, t) \ w}{2 v + 2 b \epsilon \pi(s, t) / 3}) \\\\ &\le 2 \exp ( - \frac{ \epsilon^2 \pi^2(s, t) \ w}{2 b \pi(s, t) + 2 b \epsilon \pi(s, t) / 3}) \\\\ &\le 2 \exp ( - \frac{ \epsilon^2 \pi (s, t) \ w}{b (2 + 2\epsilon / 3)}) \\\\ &\le p_{fail} \end{align}

So

w≥b2+2ϵ/3ϵ2δlog⁡2pfailw \ge b \frac{2 + 2\epsilon / 3}{\epsilon^2 \delta} \log \frac{2}{p_{fail} } w≥bϵ2δ2+2ϵ/3​logpfail​2​

We would like to minimize bbb in order to minimize www, which can be formulated as an convex optimization problem:

\begin{align} \min \quad &b \\\\ s.t. \quad &b \ge r(s, v_i) / k_i \\\\ &\sum_i k_i = 1 \\\\ &k_i \ge 0 \end{align}

Here we rewrite wiw=ki\frac{w_i}{w} = k_iwwi​​=ki​. One simple way to solve this is to guess that bbb is minimized when all r(s,vi)/ki{r(s, v_i)}/{k_i}r(s,vi​)/ki​ equals. This gives ki=r(s,vi)/rsumk_i = r(s, v_i) / r_{sum}ki​=r(s,vi​)/rsum​. We can prove this is indeed optimal: if this is not the case, there must be some ki<r(s,vi)/rsumk_i < r(s, v_i) / r_{sum}ki​<r(s,vi​)/rsum​. Then b≥r(s,vi)/ki>rsumb \ge r(s, v_i) / k_i > r_{sum}b≥r(s,vi​)/ki​>rsum​ .

We can also solve this problem by a heavy mechanism: KKT conditions. First, define

L(b,k,λ,β,,μ)=b+∑i=1nλi(r(s,vi)/ki−b)+∑i=1nβi(0−ki)+μ(∑i=1nki−1)L(b, k, \lambda, \beta, , \mu) = b + \sum_{i = 1}^n \lambda_i (r(s, v_i) / k_i - b) + \sum_{i = 1}^n \beta_i (0 - k_i) + \mu (\sum_{i = 1}^n k_i - 1) L(b,k,λ,β,,μ)=b+i=1∑n​λi​(r(s,vi​)/ki​−b)+i=1∑n​βi​(0−ki​)+μ(i=1∑n​ki​−1)

Thus, the KKT conditions are

\begin{align} & r(s, v_i) / k_i - b \le 0 &\forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ & -k_i \le 0 &\forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ & \sum_i k_i - 1 = 0 \\\\ & \lambda_i \ge 0, \beta_i \ge 0 &\forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ & \lambda_i (r(s, v_i) / k_i - b) = 0 &\forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ &\beta_i (0 - k_i) = 0 &\forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ & \frac{\partial L}{\partial b} = 1 - \sum_{i = 1}^n \lambda_i = 0 \\\\ & \frac{\partial L}{\partial k_i} = -\lambda_i r(s, v_i) / k_i^2 - \beta_i + \mu = 0 &\forall i \in [1, n]\\\\ \end{align}

So one solution is given by

\begin{align} &b = r_{sum} \\\\ &k_i = r(s, v_i) / r_{sum} & \forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ &\lambda_i = r(s, v_i) / r_{sum}^2 & \forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ &\beta_i = 0 & \forall i \in [1, n] \\\\ &\mu = 1 \end{align}

which implies

w≥b2+2ϵ/3ϵ2δlog⁡2pfailwi=wki=wr(s,vi)rsumw \ge b \frac{2 + 2\epsilon / 3}{\epsilon^2 \delta} \log \frac{2}{p_{fail} } \\\\ w_i = w k_i = \frac{w r(s, v_i)}{r_{sum} } w≥bϵ2δ2+2ϵ/3​logpfail​2​wi​=wki​=rsum​wr(s,vi​)​

Lebesgue Measure

It is quiet intuitive that intervals (a,b),(a,b],[a,b),[a,b](a,b),(a,b],[a,b),[a,b](a,b),(a,b],[a,b),[a,b] have length b−ab - ab−a. Now we want measure sets of real numbers more general than intervals, such as the set of all rational numbers.

In order to do so, we need a new model, a new concept of length. Before we show what Lebesgue Measure is, it is natural to have following question in mind:

**1. What do we mean when we talk about the length of a set? **
2. Does every set has a length?
3. What properties do the sets that have length satisfy?

One way to think of length of sets is regarding it as a function from sets to real numbers. Translating the above questions into the language of functions, we get

1. What is the function?
2. Especially, what is the domain of the function?
3. What are the typical properties of the function?

Before we delve into the details of constructing Lebesgue Measure, we shows some important goals of that construction (We forgo why we need such goals for the moment. Yet again, keep this question in mind):

  1. Intervals like (a,b],[a,b],[a,b),(a,b)(a,b],[a,b],[a,b),(a,b)(a,b],[a,b],[a,b),(a,b) are measurable and have length b−ab - ab−a.
    . If set EEE is measurable, then its complement E‾\overline{E}E is measurable.
    . Countable unions of measurable sets are measurable.

One immediate corollary of goal (2) and (3) is that

4 . Countable intersections of measurable sets are measurable.

Actually, if we replace (3) with (4), we can derive (3) by combining (2) and (4). This is due to the symmetry inherent in set operation

E1∪E2‾=E1‾∩E2‾\overline{E_1 \cup E_2} = \overline{E_1} \cap \overline{E_2} E1​∪E2​​=E1​​∩E2​​

Another corollary of (1), (2) and (3) is

5 . Countable intersections and unions of intervals are measurable.

Two Components for Lebesgue Measure

  1. m∗(E)≐inf⁡{∑nl(In):In is open interval and E⊂∪nIn}m^*(E) \doteq \inf \{ \sum_n l(I_n) : I_n \ \text{is open interval and } E \subset \cup_n I_n\}m∗(E)≐inf{∑n​l(In​):In​ is open interval and E⊂∪n​In​}, where l(In)l(I_n)l(In​) denotes the length of InI_nIn​.
  2. For any set A, a measurable set E must satisfy m∗(A)≥m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩E‾)m^*(A) \ge m^*(A \cap E) + m^*(A \cap \overline{E})m∗(A)≥m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩E).

Discussion:
(1) is a quiet intuitive rule. It states the length of a set is the least upper bound(supermum) of the sum of length of open intervals whose union covers this set. But why don’t we use the sum of lengths of intervals that constitute the set as the length of this set?
One possible explanation is that there are sets which are not countable unions or intersection intervals. So we have to use open intervals to approximate them. What do these set look like? Keep this question in mind.

(2) The second condition is required so that we find a set of sets that are close under complement, countable union and intersection operation with respect to the length definition of (1). Yet why (1) alone is not enough?. We will tough more about this issue when we come to non-Lebusgue measurable sets.

More formally, let

L={E:∀A⊂R, m∗(A)≥m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩E‾),where m∗(E)≐inf⁡{∑nl(In):In is open interval and E⊂∪nIn}}\begin{aligned} \mathfrak{L} = \{ &E: \forall A \subset R, \ m^*(A) \ge m^*(A \cap E) + m^*(A \cap \overline{E}), \\\\ & where \ m^*(E) \doteq \inf \{ \sum_n l(I_n) : I_n \ \text{is open interval and } E \subset \cup_n I_n\} \} \end{aligned} L={​E:∀A⊂R, m∗(A)≥m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩E),where m∗(E)≐inf{n∑​l(In​):In​ is open interval and E⊂∪n​In​}}​

we will show that

  1. [a,b],[a,b),(a,b],(a,b)∈L[a,b], [a,b), (a,b], (a,b) \in \mathfrak{L}[a,b],[a,b),(a,b],(a,b)∈L, and m∗([a,b])=m∗([a,b))=m∗((a,b])=m∗((a,b))=b−am^*([a,b])=m^*([a,b))=m^*((a,b])=m^*((a,b))= b - am∗([a,b])=m∗([a,b))=m∗((a,b])=m∗((a,b))=b−a.
    .∀E∈L,E‾∈L.\forall E \in \mathfrak{L}, \overline{E} \in \mathfrak{L}.∀E∈L,E∈L.
    .{En}n≥1⊂L,∪nEn∈L\{ E_n\}_{n \ge 1} \subset \mathfrak{L}, \cup_n E_n \in \mathfrak{L}{En​}n≥1​⊂L,∪n​En​∈L
    .{En}n≥1⊂L,∩nEn∈L\{ E_n\}_{n \ge 1} \subset \mathfrak{L}, \cap_n E_n \in \mathfrak{L}{En​}n≥1​⊂L,∩n​En​∈L

Before we move on, we notice the construction of L\mathfrak{L}L so far involves (a) definition of length (b) constraint on the sets involved. Is it the only way of constructing L?\mathfrak{L}?L? In other words, if we replace (a) or (b) with something else, we get a new set L′\mathfrak{L'}L′. Will L′\mathfrak{L'}L′ satisfy the above four properties? Measure Theory studies these general topics.

Theorem

∀E∈L,E‾∈L.\forall E \in \mathfrak{L}, \overline{E} \in \mathfrak{L}.∀E∈L,E∈L.

Proof: Straightforward from definition of L\mathfrak{L}L.

Lema

If E⊂∪nEn, then m∗(E)≤∑nm∗(En)E \subset \cup_n E_n, \text{ then } m^*(E) \le \sum_n m^*(E_n)E⊂∪n​En​, then m∗(E)≤∑n​m∗(En​).

Proof: If ∑nm∗(En)=∞\sum_n m^*(E_n) = \infty∑n​m∗(En​)=∞ then, this is obvious. Otherwise, for each n, m∗(En)≤∞m^*(E_n) \le \inftym∗(En​)≤∞, so there exist an set of open intervals {Ikn}\{I_k^n \}{Ikn​}, s.t.,

En⊂∪kIknm∗(En)+ϵ2n≥∑kl(Ikn)E_n \subset \cup_k I_k^n \\ m^*(E_n) + {\epsilon \over 2^n}\ge \sum_k l(I_k^n)En​⊂∪k​Ikn​m∗(En​)+2nϵ​≥∑k​l(Ikn​)

But {Ikn:k≥1,n≥1}\{I_k^n : k \ge 1, n \ge 1\}{Ikn​:k≥1,n≥1} is a cover of E, so

m∗(E)≤∑n∑kl(Ikn)≤∑n(m∗(En)+ϵ2n)=∑nm∗(En)+ϵm^*(E) \le \sum_n \sum_k l(I_k^n) \le \sum_n (m^*(E_n) + {\epsilon \over 2^n}) = \sum_n m^*(E_n) + \epsilon m∗(E)≤n∑​k∑​l(Ikn​)≤n∑​(m∗(En​)+2nϵ​)=n∑​m∗(En​)+ϵ

As ϵ\epsilonϵ takes arbitrary values, we have proved the inequality.

Corollary

If E⊂E1, then m∗(E)≤m∗(E1)\text{If } E \subset E_1, \text{ then } m^*(E) \le m^*(E_1)If E⊂E1​, then m∗(E)≤m∗(E1​).
